dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Facebook's new partnership with FBI Director Christopher Wray is a huge shift, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Facebook's new partnership with F B I Director Christopher Wray is a huge shift, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: FBI Director Christopher Wray has also been critical of Facebooks plan to encrypt all of its users messages in the near future. Wray says that it would be a dream come true for child pornographers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they included Instagram data for the first time in that transparency report—that's pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they included Instagram data for the first time in that transparency report-that's pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company revealed its sweeping efforts to police its own network in its latest biannual transparency report, which includes data from Instagram for the first time.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? But even with better AI detection, they actually removed less child exploitation content last quarter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? But even with better A I detection, they actually removed less child exploitation content last quarter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook says that it removed about 11.6 million pieces of content it deemed to be child nudity and sexual exploitation of children in the third quarter, roughly double the number of pieces of content removed for the same reason in the first quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, really? They said 1.2 million pieces in Q3, down from earlier? That's… surprising.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, really? They said one point two million pieces in Q3, down from earlier? That's... surprising.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Instagram, it removed 1.2 million photos and videos involving child nudity or exploitation over the second and third quarters.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and on Instagram it was 11.6 million over two quarters. But Zuckerberg says they're "succeeding in minimizing impact," not just working harder.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and on Instagram it was eleven point six million over two quarters. But Zuckerberg says they're succeeding in minimizing impact, not just working harder.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook says that it removed about 11.6 million pieces of content it deemed to be child nudity and sexual exploitation of children in the third quarter, roughly double the number of pieces of content removed for the same reason in the first quarter. What it says is were working harder to identify this and take action on it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm, I'm though—isn't that a little contradictory? Fewer removals but calling it success?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm, I'm though-isn't that a little contradictory? Fewer removals but calling it success?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Well, their new strategy is identifying stuff after users report it, which critics actually like. But then there's the encryption expansion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, their new strategy is identifying stuff after users report it, which critics actually like. But then there's the encryption expansion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook says it identifies most of the content automatically using artificial intelligence and advanced software before users can ever see it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, end-to-end encryption across all services—even Rep. Ann Wagner supports it, called it crucial.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, end-to-end encryption across all services-even Rep. Ann Wagner supports it, called it crucial.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Representative Ann Wagner (R-MO) scolded Zuckerberg at the hearing, saying, You are not working hard enough, and end-to-end encryption is not going to help the problem.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And get this—FBI Director Wray used to oppose encryption, but now he's praising Facebook's message privacy efforts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And get this-F B I Director Wray used to oppose encryption, but now he's praising Facebook's message privacy efforts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: FBI Director Christopher Wray has also been critical of Facebooks plan to encrypt all of its users messages in the near future. Wray says that it would be a dream come true for child pornographers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's a total reversal! And The Wall Street Journal reported WhatsApp only had 100,000 reports of child abuse material recently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a total reversal! And The Wall Street Journal reported WhatsApp only had one hundred thousand reports of child abuse material recently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The New York Times in September claimed that Facebook Messenger was responsible for nearly 12 million of the 18.4 million worldwide reports of child sexual abuse material.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Zuckerberg did express concern though—said the vast amount of this content is hurting society.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Zuckerberg did express concern though-said the vast amount of this content is hurting society.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During a press call with reporters on Wednesday, Zuckerberg responded to concerns about the vast amount of child exploitation content found on the companys networks, claiming that it was actually a positive thing for the industry and society.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But he also claimed encryption will help them see violating content easier? That part confused me a bit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But he also claimed encryption will help them see violating content easier? That part confused me a bit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At a high level youre pointing to a real tension, which is that encryption makes it harder for us to see some of the content in the services, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he said it makes it easier to see some content, but also prevents stuff that violates terms. Pattern detection too—and hiring people with criminal records for moderation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he said it makes it easier to see some content, but also prevents stuff that violates terms. Pattern detection too-and hiring people with criminal records for moderation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At a high level youre pointing to a real tension, which is that encryption makes it harder for us to see some of the content in the services, he said. JPMorgan Chase Hired 2,100 People With Criminal Records In 2018 (And Will Hire More)

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa, hiring folks with records? That's an interesting approach to policing illegal activity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa, hiring folks with records? That's an interesting approach to policing illegal activity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely a layered strategy—tech, policy, human oversight. Let's see how it actually plays out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely a layered strategy-tech, policy, human oversight. Let's see how it actually plays out.

artist_script:
HostA: Facebook's new partnership with FBI Director Christopher Wray is a huge shift, honestly.
HostB: Yeah, and they included Instagram data for the first time in that transparency report—that’s pretty significant.
HostA: Right? But even with better AI detection, they actually removed less child exploitation content last quarter.
HostB: Wait, really? They said 1.2 million pieces in Q3, down from earlier? That’s… surprising.
HostA: Yeah, and on Instagram it was 11.6 million over two quarters. But Zuckerberg says they’re “succeeding in minimizing impact,” not just working harder.
HostB: Hmm, I’m though—isn’t that a little contradictory? Fewer removals but calling it success?
HostA: Well, their new strategy is identifying stuff after users report it, which critics actually like. But then there’s the encryption expansion.
HostB: Oh yeah, end-to-end encryption across all services—even Rep. Ann Wagner supports it, called it crucial.
HostA: And get this—FBI Director Wray used to oppose encryption, but now he’s praising Facebook’s message privacy efforts.
HostB: That’s a total reversal! And The Wall Street Journal reported WhatsApp only had 100,000 reports of child abuse material recently.
HostA: Zuckerberg did express concern though—said the vast amount of this content is hurting society.
HostB: But he also claimed encryption will help them see violating content easier? That part confused me a bit.
HostA: Yeah, he said it makes it easier to see some content, but also prevents stuff that violates terms. Pattern detection too—and hiring people with criminal records for moderation.
HostB: Whoa, hiring folks with records? That’s an interesting approach to policing illegal activity.
HostA: Definitely a layered strategy—tech, policy, human oversight. Let’s see how it actually plays out.
